item.title: Oil Gains as Fed Meeting Set to Begin
item.description: Oil prices recovered some of their steep previous-session losses, with investors eyeing Wednesday’s Fed decision for broader economic projections and crude demand expectations, ING said.

item.title: Sterling Could Remain Supported in Near-Term After UK Jobs Data
item.description: Sterling should remain supported in the near-term after data showed “ultra-tight” U.K. labor market conditions, ING said, adding that sticky wage inflation means “very low chances” of the BOE cutting interest rates before 2024.

item.title: Metals Prices Push Higher Ahead of U.S. Inflation Data
item.description: Base metals and gold prices rose in early London trading, as investors looked to U.S. inflation data, but strong economic activity suggests a hawkish Fed in the short term, which could see the gold price consolidating, ANZ said.

item.title: U.S. Troops Injured in Syria Helicopter Incident
item.description: Twenty-two members of the U.S. military were injured in a helicopter incident in northern Syria over the weekend, U.S. Central Command said.

item.title: Ubisoft's Assassin's Creed Mirage Should Be Released on Time
item.description: Ubisoft’s Assassin’s Creed Mirage game looks polished and the chances for a release delay are low, Jefferies said following a game showcase event.

item.title: Italian BTPs Seen Most Favored in Five- to 10-Year Maturity Bucket
item.description: Risk appetite is supportive for Italian government bonds, with the five to 10-year maturity segment being most favored, boding well for today’s auction, Mizuho said.

item.title: Centrica Confident on Full-Year Outcome
item.description: Centrica said its performance in the first five months of the year has been strong overall, and it expects adjusted earnings to be around the top end of market expectations.

item.title: German Inflation Falls in May, Confirming Estimates
item.description: Germany’s consumer price index increased 6.1% in May, in line with preliminary estimates, after energy costs eased further, though underlying pressures on household spending remained strong.

item.title: UK Jobless Rate Falls But No Sign of Slowing Wages
item.description: The U.K.’s unemployment rate fell to 3.8% in the three months to April, reversing recent rises, but pay growth continued to edge up.

item.title: China's Central Bank Moves to Shore Up Recovery
item.description: Unexpected trim in key lending rate likely heralds further steps to stimulate China’s economy.

item.title: Colombian Children Survived on Fruit, Nuts and Wits After Crash in Amazon Jungle
item.description: After escaping the wreckage of a plane crash that killed their mother, four children wandered for a month, suffering from malnourishment and dehydration before being found.

item.title: The Denver Nuggets Win Their First NBA Title
item.description: The Denver Nuggets won their first NBA championship, beating the Miami Heat in five games.

item.title: Renters Are About to Get the Upper Hand
item.description: New-lease rents are poised to fall on an annual basis for only the second time since 2008 financial crisis.

item.title: Renters Are About to Get the Upper Hand
item.description: New-lease rents are poised to fall on an annual basis for only the second time since the 2008 financial crisis.

item.title: Stock-Market Bulls See Room to Run
item.description: Sentiment is improving ahead of the release of key economic data and the Fed’s interest-rate decision.

item.title: First It Was Quiet Quitting, Now Workers Are Facing Off With Their Bosses
item.description: Employee frustrations impact productivity and worker retention, Gallup says.

item.title: A former Samsung executive was indicted in South Korea, accused of starting a company that attracted about $6 billion in investments to build a China-based chip factory using Samsung's factory blueprints and other engineering secrets.
item.description: A former Samsung executive was indicted in South Korea, accused of starting a company that attracted about $6 billion in investments to build a China-based chip factory using Samsung’s factory blueprints and other engineering secrets.

item.title: JPMorgan agreed to pay $290 million to settle a lawsuit over its ties toJeffrey Epstein shortly after top executives were questioned about the bank's years of dealings with the convicted sex offender. The suit on behalf of women who accused Epstein of abuse helped expose details about JPMorgan's relationship with him.
item.description: JPMorgan agreed to pay $290 million to settle a lawsuit over its ties to Jeffrey Epstein shortly after top executives were questioned about the bank’s years of dealings with the convicted sex offender. The suit on behalf of women who accused Epstein of abuse helped expose details about JPMorgan’s relationship with him.

item.title: EU antitrust regulators are considering pursuing a breakup of Google's ad-tech business as part of a new antitrust complaint, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.description: EU antitrust regulators are considering pursuing a breakup of Google’s ad-tech business as part of a new antitrust complaint, according to people familiar with the matter.

item.title: Nasdaq agreed to acquire financial-software maker Adenza in a $10.5 billion cash-and-stock deal that represents the most ambitious move yet in CEO Friedman's efforts to reshape her company.
item.description: Nasdaq agreed to acquire financial-software maker Adenza in a $10.5 billion cash-and-stock deal that represents the most ambitious move yet in CEO Friedman’s efforts to reshape her company.
